group_1.textCenter: Thank you all for taking time out of your busy@schedules,
Let's start off by discussing the changes to the@school rules.
First of all, we would like to hear the opinions@of the Parents' Association...

group_1.narration: "About the school rules on hair color@and hairstyle, right?@To change the rules is outrageous."
"Students are supposed to be studying@first and foremost, not worrying about@their appearance."
"It was like that back in our day,@so why shouldn't you kids put up with it too?"

group_1.textCenter: ...Well, don't you think it's also important to let@students develop their individuality?

group_1.narration: "My worry is that if they dress too flashy,@they might fall in with the wrong crowd."

group_1.textCenter: So it's for protecting the students, you mean.

group_1.narration: "I can see where the Parents' Association@is coming from..."
"They say that disordered dress@leads to disordered morals."
"No matter how upright you are on the inside,@if you stand out too much with your looks,@you may give off the wrong impression..."
"When you step out into the world,@you may be expected to be the same as everyone else...@So it's also a way of practicing for that."

group_1.textCenter: I can see all your thoughtfulness towards us@students.

group_1.narration: "How many of our problems are really caused by looks?"
"Conversely, how many problems have we had@because of the restraint *imposed* on looks?"
"What the teachers and the Parents' Association@are talking about is only to prevent problems@before they happen."
"Which is also important, but if by applying@enforcement you're causing problems to occur, then@doesn't that defeat the whole purpose?"

group_1.textCenter: Besides, there are many prep schools these days@that permit students to dress freely.
Because they value autonomy in their education.

group_1.narration: "Freedom does not mean you can do@whatever you want.@It means you have to think for yourself,@and act responsibly."
"This may be a bit further down the road for@some students, but being able to think for yourself will@be a necessary skill for job hunting as well."
"I've heard that students who were forced@to be like everyone else during their school years@are often confused when they are suddenly asked@to be 'unique' in their job interviews."
"That is because they've only been allowed to@follow a predetermined path known as@the 'rules' up until that point."
"I believe that granting your kids freedom@does not mean spoiling them."
"Rather, it offers a great opportunity for students@to develop their own autonomy."
